subject: Re: [junit] Re: Anyway to dynamically change name of test  passed to formatter?
msgSnippet: ... private int side1; private int side2; private int side3; private int expectedVolume; public TestVolume(int side1, int side2, int side3, int expectedVolume)
messageBody:
>So said tjporterxx on 2003-06-01 --------------------
>Thanks for the quick reply, especially on a Saturday night!
>
>I'm missing something here, since I could not integrate your code
>fragments into my code. I probably do not have the hierarchy of JUnit
>objects and methods clear yet.
>
>Here is my little test case, perhaps you could fit your code into it
>as an example? Instead of the loop structure you indicated, for this
>particular case I assume I would use two suite.addTest(...) calls.
>
>Ah Hah! Lightbulb just lit up:
>
>I _think_ I understand that I have to extend TestCase into a
>ParameterizedTestCase, then have TestVol extend ParameterizedTestCase
>instead of TestCase. In that case, I cannot fit your code fragments
>into the code for TestVol directly, but must create a separate
>ParameterizedTestCase.java file and then the ParameterizedTestCase
>class file to be imported into TestVol.
>
>------------------------------------------------------
>import junit.framework.Test;
>import junit.framework.TestCase;
>import junit.framework.TestSuite;
>import junit.textui.TestRunner;
>
>/**
>* @author tporter
>*
>* To change the template for this generated type comment go to
>* Window>Preferences>Java>Code Generation>Code and Comments
>*/
>public class TestVolume extends TestCase {
> // test objects
>
private int side1;
private int side2;
private int side3;
private int expectedVolume;

public TestVolume(int side1, int side2, int side3, int expectedVolume) {
super(makeTestName(side1, side2, side3);
this.side1 = side1;
this.side2 = side2;
this.side3 = side3;
this.expectedVolume = expectedVolume;
}

private static String makeTestName(int side1, int side2, int side3) {
return "VolumeTestCase<" + side1 + ", " + side2 + ", " + side3 + ">";
}

public static Test suite() {
int[][] testData = new int[][] {
{ 2, 2, 2, 8 },
{ 1, 2, 3, 6 },
{ 2, 3, 2, 12 }
};

TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
for (int i = 0; i < testData.length; i++) {
int[] eachTestData = testData[i];
suite.addTest(new TestVolume(eachTestData[0], eachTestData[1], eachTestData[2], eachTestData[3]);
}
return suite;
}

public void testCalculateVolume() {
assertEquals(expectedVolume, new Volume().calculateVolume(side1, side2, side3));
}
>
>}

That's one way to do it. I typed this code into my e-mail client, so there's no guarantee it compiles. Fix as needed.

BTW: don't abbreviate. Abbreviations confuse.
